title: The Fed has succeeded in one way — it's reduced wealth inequality, this analysis finds; Critical information for the U.S. trading day
text:
There's some good news, from the Fed's rate hike campaign so far. As Wolf Richter of the Wolf Street blog points out, wealth inequality has been reduced.

Drawing on data both from the Federal Reserve and the Commerce Department, he calculated the change in average wealth per household, from the end of 2021 through the third quarter.

Wealth category Average wealth Change in dollars Change in % Top 0.1% $132.4 million -$13 million -9% Remaining 1% $19.3 million -$2.4 million -11.2% Next 9% $4.4 million -$269,000 -5.8% Next 40% $768,000 -$16,500 -2.1% Bottom 50% $70,800 +$10,800 +18.1%

"The Bottom 50% own almost no stocks and mutual funds, which is why a stock-market swoon doesn't faze them. Most of their assets are their home and 'consumer durables.' Consumer durables are things like cars, appliances, electronics, etc., whose value depreciates," says Richter.

It's worth reading his full analysis here.

The market

U.S. stock futures ES00 NQ00were pointing to a second day of gains. Oil futures CL.1 were trading just below $77 per barrel. The yield on the 10-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD10Y was 3.68%.

For more market updates plus actionable trade ideas for stocks, options and crypto, subscribe to MarketDiem by Investor's Business Daily.

The buzz

FedEx FDX shares climbed 5% in premarket trade as the delivery service promised an extra $1 billion in cost cuts. Year-over-year, volumes fell by 12.7% for U.S. overnight deliveries, but revenue growth in that segment was nearly flat thanks to price rises.

Nike NKE shares surged 13% after the apparel maker's earnings and sales beat expectationsas it showed signs of getting inventory under control.

Tesla TSLA rose 2% in early premarket trade, after ending 8% lower on Tuesday. Tesla CEO Elon Musk said he'll resign as Twitter CEO when he finds a replacement.

Existing home sales data is due for release at 10 a.m. Eastern, with the Conference Board's consumer confidence report due at the same time.

Starbucks SBUX was downgraded to hold from buy at Jefferies after the coffee retailer's 40% rally from its lows in May has the stock approaching the broker's $100 price target.

Alphabet's GOOGL YouTube is in talks to get the rights to the NFL's Sunday Ticket program from DirecTV, which is owned by AT&T T and TPG, The Wall Street Journal reported.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky is due to meet with President Joe Biden and to address Congress in his first known trip outside the country since Russia's invasion.

Best of the web

Former President Donald Trump has written off more in property taxes as a business expense than Internal Revenue Service rules appear to allow.

What a big JPMorgan fund's options positionsmean for markets (subscription required).

The bumpy road to alternative energy: a German city is giving up on hydrogen fuel-cell buses after just a year.
